Award.AwardTitle: REU site: Interdisciplinary Research Experiences in the Astronomical, Space, and Planetary Sciences
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports the Research Experiences for Undergraduates site at the University of Arkansas.

The program offers ten undergraduate students the opportunity to engage in publishable-quality research projects with scientists working at the forefront of astronomy, planetary science, and space science. Students are supported at the Arkansas Center for Space and Planetary Science for 10 weeks during the summer. Mentors are selected from the scientific staff of the center, progress within the program is monitored through weekly meetings, a mid-term 10 minute oral presentation, and a final poster presentation with a two-page abstract. Program participants will also take part in five field trip to nearby research facilities to illustrate research in a variety of environments. Students are recruited from a variety of locations with a strong emphasis on the recruitment of students from HBCU, Tribal schools, and school with limited research opportunities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Arkansas Space and Planetary Sciences REU grant operated over a three year period with the aim of providing an enriching research experience for undergraduates in the astronomical and space sciences, with a view to encouraging them to consider graduate school and a career in research. Each participating undergraduate was paired with a faculty mentor and worked within an active research group, collaborating with graduate students on their project. The program was particularly successful in attracting women, minorities and students from campuses with little active research, thus exposing to research members of groups traditionally underrepresented in research science.

A particular high point of the program was that the majority of students had the opportunity to present their research at a national research conference, usually the Lunar and Planetary Science Conference (LPSC) or the American Astronomical Society (AAS) annual winter meeting. All the students presented their research in a mid-program talk and an end-of-program poster session and wrote an abstract describing their work. Many students contributed to and were co-authors of a publication in a refereed journal.

Students participated fully in the weekly activity of their research groups, which varied from group to group, but typically included weekly research meetings or seminars, daily interactions with graduate students, postdocs or faculty and a full day of laboratory (or, in some cases, theoretical or analytical) research. In addition, the REU students met for weekly seminars as a group, learning from program faculty about a variety of topics of broad relevance to research. Most of all they learned from each other as a peer group, sharing their experiences as a cohort. The program was particularly successful in cohort building, aided by the close-knit nature of the research groups themselves, which mostly consisted of graduate students passionate about their research projects.  A highlight of the program was a variety of short trips which all REU students went on, including a trip to western Oklahoma to visit Martian-like terrain (that trip included an aquarium visit also) and a 4-day trip to the Johnson Space Center in Houston, which was hosted by a former Space Center REU participant and graduate student, now working at JSC as a postdoc. Certainly the program was rewarding for the organizers in terms of the quite visible enthusiasm of the participants.

The program was successful in its main goal of helping students to make the decision to continue on in STEM fields.  Participants are now either continuing their undergraduate eductions, in graduate school, or in high tech industries with a significant research component. The graduate schools they are attending span the U.S. from the East coast to Hawai'i.

A final successful outcome of the program has been the positive impact of the REU students upon the fundamental research in which they were engaged. The students typically worked hard for the whole summer and in a many cases were instrumental in bring important research projects to a successful conclusion. All of them contributed meaningfully in addition to those who could be described as exceptional by any standard. In astronomy, REU students helped develop and test new computer algorithms that are useful in measuring important features in galactic structure. These codes have been made publically available to other astronomers. They have contributed to a Letter and several papers in The Astrophysical Journal, the leading journal in the field. In planetary science, they played a key role in constructing and conducting simulations of conditions on other planets and moons of the solar system, a role which was instrumental in winning many major research grants subsequently for research in this area.
